Can a Smart Watch Prolong Your Life?

title: Japan retrieves rare earth-rich mud from seabed to lower reliance on China
description: Japan said Monday it has successfully drilled and retrieved deep-sea sediment containing rare earth minerals from the seabed near a remote island, as the country seeks to reduce its reliance on China.  The deep-sea drilling vessel Chikyu successfully gathered the sediment at a depth of nearly 6,000 meters (19,700 feet) near the island of Minamitorishima, Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi said in a statement on X.  The test retrieval of the rare earths from that depth is a world first, she added.
fullText:
TOKYO (AP) ‚Äî Japan said Monday it has successfully drilled and retrieved deep-sea sediment containing rare earth minerals from the seabed near a remote island, as the country seeks to reduce its reliance on China.

The deep-sea drilling vessel Chikyu successfully gathered the sediment at a depth of nearly 6,000 meters (19,700 feet) near the island of Minamitorishima, Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi said in a statement on X.

The test retrieval of the rare earths from that depth is a world first, she added.

‚ÄúIt is a first step toward industrialization of domestically produced rare earth in Japan,‚Äù Takaichi said. ‚ÄúWe will make effort toward achieving resilient supply chains for rare earths and other critical minerals to avoid overdependence on a particular country."

China controls most of the global production of heavy rare earths, which are used for making powerful, heat-resistant magnets in industries such as defense and electric vehicles.

Japan has faced growing tensions with China since Takaichi's comment in November about a possible Japanese involvement in case of Chinese military action against Taiwan, the self-governing island that Beijing claims as its own.

China recently suspended exports to Japan of dual-use goods with potential military use, raising concern in Japan that rare earths may be included.

While 17 elements are classified as rare earth, the U.S. government has identified 50 minerals overall that are labeled critical minerals, which also include a number of other minerals that are seen as essential to the economic and military strength of the nation.

Japanese researchers discovered deposits rich with critical minerals including rare earths around Minamitorishima in the 2010s.

Under the Strategic Innovation Promotion Program, Japan has been working on research, development and feasibility studies of rare earths deposits around the island.

‚ÄúThe successful retrieval of the sediment containing rare earth elements is a meaningful achievement from the perspectives of economic security and comprehensive ocean development,‚Äù Japan‚Äôs Deputy Chief Cabinet Secretary Masanao Ozaki said Monday.

He said that moving toward industrialization of rare earths mud mining will require demonstrating the full process from mining through separation and refining, as well as verifying its economic viability, based on the results of the ongoing tests.

Details, including the amount of rare earth contained, still need to be analyzed, officials said.

The Chikyu, which means Earth, departed last month for Minamitorishima, about 1,950 kilometers (1,210 miles) southeast of Tokyo, and arrived at the mining site on Jan. 17. The first batch of rare earth sediment was retrieved on Feb. 1, according to Japan's Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology, which is conducting the survey.

Japan‚Äôs Self Defense Forces last year said Chinese naval vessels had been spotted near Minamitorishima.

This story corrects the metric of the depth to meters from kilometers.

AP video journalist Mayuko Ono in Tokyo contributed to this report.

title: Broadcom and TSMC to emerge as big winners in the custom AI chip boom
description: Nvidia still reigns, but a structural shift toward custom silicon is creating a new hierarchy of winners and laggards, and analysts are split.
fullText:
The AI chip race isn't just a one-horse sprint led by Nvidia (NVDA).

As hyperscalers like Google (GOOG, GOOGL), Meta (META), and Microsoft (MSFT) race to lower the eye-watering costs of running massive AI models, a second front is opening in the custom silicon wars, with Broadcom (AVGO) as its primary architect.

What challenges do custom chip companies face currently?

What advantages do custom ASICs offer over Nvidia GPUs?

How is Broadcom competing with Nvidia in AI chips?

Why is TSMC crucial to the AI chip market?

"Broadcom is projected to retain its leadership as the premier AI Server Compute ASIC design partner with a 60% market share in 2027," according to a recent report from Counterpoint Research.

This dominance is underpinned by a symbiotic relationship with the world's most advanced foundry, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSM), which remains the "dominant foundry choice ... with close to 99% wafer fabrication share for the top 10 players' AI Server Compute and ASIC shipments."

This shift signals the industry is moving beyond Nvidia's pricey, all-purpose GPUs. While Nvidia provides a powerful all-purpose AI tool, tech giants are increasingly designing their own Application-Specific Integrated Circuits (ASICS) tailored to their unique workloads.

Broadcom thrives here by acting as the bridge, turning these internal corporate blueprints into functional hardware. By hitching its wagon to the internal capital expenditures of the world's wealthiest companies, Broadcom has seen its stock climb roughly 55% over the last year.

The cost-saving incentive for these giants is massive. Goldman Sachs analyst James Schneider noted that the Google-Broadcom TPU (Tensor Processing Unit) is rapidly closing the performance gap with Nvidia, estimating a staggering 70% reduction in "cost-per-token" as the technology evolves from the TPU v6 to the v7.

In a world where AI inference costs can severely impact a balance sheet, that efficiency is a powerful gravitational pull toward custom silicon. Google famously trained its Gemini 3 entirely on its TPUs.

However, the custom chip boom is not a rising tide that lifts all boats equally. Marvell Technology (MRVL), often cited as Broadcom's primary challenger, is currently navigating "design win headwinds." Counterpoint's analysis suggests Marvell's design service share could slide to 8% by 2027, even as its total shipment volumes grow.

Goldman Sachs remains Neutral on Marvell with a $90 price target, noting that the company's fortunes are heavily tied to Amazon Trainium program, which has faced its own performance hurdles and is oftentimes seen as playing catch-up to Nvidia's chips.

While some on Wall Street, like Raymond James analyst Simon Leopold, remain bullish on Marvell as a long-term "share gainer," the immediate data favors Broadcom's grip on high-volume contracts. The firm issued a Strong Buy rating on Marvell with a $121 price target, while giving Broadcom a $420 target.

title: Judge retires after 17 years on the bench and nearly 38 in Lafayette
description: Like so many Lafayette immigrant stories, Judge Randy Williams‚Äô story involved a love and Purdue University.
fullText:
Anyone who ever spent any time in Tippecanoe Superior 1 over the last 17 years likely noticed Judge Randy Williams‚Äô upstate New York accent. Sometimes, it's hard to miss.

Even though Williams has lived here for nearly 40 years, his accent persists.

So how does a New Yorker settle in small-town Indiana?

Like so many immigrant stories of Lafayette transplants, Williams‚Äô story involved a love and Purdue.

As a young attorney practicing first in Albany, New York, and later in his hometown of Rome, New York, Williams never imagined a career in a mostly quiet Midwestern city.

That was before he met and dated Shay Daley.

‚ÄúShay came out here in the summer '87, starting with her master's program in clinical psychology,‚Äù Williams said, noting he was working for a law firm in Rome. ‚ÄúWe had the long-distance thing going on.

‚ÄúAnd at one point, I think the suggestion was, ‚ÄòWell, why don't you move out here?‚Äô And I said, ‚ÄòI'm not going to move out there unless we're married.‚Äô"

So much for a surprise engagement.

‚ÄúWe got engaged in March of '88, got married in July of '88,‚Äù Williams recalled.

They honeymooned, and then Williams moved to Lafayette, where he briefly lived the life of an unemployed lawyer.

‚ÄúNow, honestly, did I think I'd be here, you know, 37 years?‚Äù Williams rhetorically asked. ‚ÄúOnce I did get here, there were a few (law) firms that thought, ‚ÄòOh, you're just here. You're a short-timer, so why would we even bother?‚Äô I think that was the attitude.‚Äù

To earn money, Williams started substitute teaching. During a world civics class, they were studying Rome ‚Äî the empire in Europe and Africa, not his hometown.

When he shared with the students he was from Rome, they started asking him how an unemployed attorney found himself substitute teaching in front of a Jefferson High School class. Long story short, one of the students, Annie Deets, was in the class.

The next day, Williams got a call from a local attorney and Annie Deets's father, Charles, who interviewed him and hired him.

For the next 17 years, Williams built his career here as an attorney, first at Deets law firm then at Ball Eggleston law firm.

‚ÄúMaybe at that point, I was thinking we'll stay around a while,‚Äù he joked of his early days in the community as he built his law practice.

Through the years, Williams and Daley bought a house, which was only supposed to be their five-year home, he said. They still live there today after more than 35 years. They became parents there to a daughter, Rachel, and a son, Sam.

He started an unofficial career as a soccer coach, first for his daughter's team, then for other teams. He'd played four years of soccer at Hamilton College in Clinton, New York, back in the 1970s when the game's popularity was low, so he knew more than most about the game.

He retired three times from coaching soccer before it finally stuck in 2020 during the COVID-19 outbreak.

As for notable cases while he was a defense attorney, none stands out, he said. ‚ÄúI was unassuming,‚Äù he joked.

Williams' law career took a turn in 2008.

‚ÄúIt was time," Williams said of his run for Tippecanoe Superior 1 judge. "There was a court that was going to be open, and I had done a lot of work in here as a (temporary) judge. I had tried cases. I had been reversed."

Williams didn't see running for judge as an entitlement or a calling.

‚ÄúThere wasn't the thought that this is what I was was born and raised to do. It wasn't," he said. "I thought I could help, I guess."

Running for public office required his family consent, he said.

‚ÄúThere were family discussions because, you know, if your dad becomes a judge, you may hear things, you may read things, see things that you may not like. Is that something you'll be OK with?‚Äù he said recalling the family talks before his run for office.

Through the 17 years on the bench, Williams said most of the cases stand out for one reason or another, but he chose not to comment on any specific cases. In some, there might be post-conviction motions pending.

On the afternoon of Friday, Jan. 16, friends, colleagues, peers and well-wishers stopped by the Superior 1 courtroom to celebrate Williams's retirement with him.

Indiana Supreme Court Chief Justice Loretta Rush was among those who visited, as were defense attorneys, other judges, deputy prosecutors, bailiffs, and many of Williams's friends.

Steve Meyer, who plans to retire as Tippecanoe Superior 2 judge next year, worked with Williams at the Ball Eggleston law firm, where they molded a friendship that continued in their respective roles as judges.

Meyer attended Williams's retirement shindig Friday, Jan. 16 ‚Äî two days before a gunman shot Meyer and his wife, Kim. Both are going to make a full recovery.

But the shooting, as well as Meyer's participation in this profile, made it seem necessary to postpone publishing this story until it was known whether Meyer and his wife would be OK.

Meyer and Williams came up through their careers as defense attorneys.

Meyer telephoned Williams on Jan. 20, two days after the shooting, Williams said last week.

‚ÄúIt was like the weight of the world had been lifted from my shoulders to hear him,‚Äù Williams said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good to hear him.‚Äù

The shooting caused ripple effects for judges throughout the state, and Rush, a Lafayette resident, has spoken with the state's judges and justices about the situation.

Prosecutors allege that Meyer's shooting was a criminal gang activity intended to stop Thomas Moss' Jan. 20 trial on gun, domestic battery and criminal recklessness.

Cases are randomly assigned to courts, and Williams recognized that Meyer's shooting could have been happened to any judge to whom the case was assigned.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to think about it too much,‚Äù Williams said about the random draw. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be a little more cautious now.‚Äù

Initially, Williams wondered whether the shooting might be political because Meyer is the only Democrat judge.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know. You just don‚Äôt know,‚Äù he said, referring to the strife and division in society at this point in history. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a scary thing.‚Äù

The judges have pulled together to keep Tippecanoe Superior 2 on track with hearings and trials.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just so glad that he‚Äôll be back. We don‚Äôt know when,‚Äù Williams said. ‚ÄúI think the judges have stayed strong and done a really nice job."

‚ÄúHe's a good friend, and he's probably my closest friend in the local judiciary,‚Äù Meyer said during a Jan. 12 interview in his office.

‚ÄúHe's a great sounding board because when things happen, I know I can always go to him and maybe run an idea by or discuss an issue, and he does the same with me," Meyer said in an interview before the shooting. "I always get, I think, reliable, sound feedback that I appreciate.‚Äù

‚ÄúI'm actually going to miss seeing him on regular basis and miss his advice and sounding board," Meyer said.

Before Meyer became Judge Meyer, he at times defended clients in Williams's court.

‚ÄúI think he always had a pretty good temperament, pretty fair and balanced, and I always knew that I'd get a good hearing there,‚Äù Meyer said.

Tippecanoe County Prosecutor Pat Harrington became familiar with Williams while they were both up-and-coming defense attorneys.

‚ÄúHe is a solid judge," Harrington said. ‚ÄúHe is always consistent in his interpretation of the law, and he's always polite.‚Äù

‚ÄúToday we go into court on high-tech crime evidence, and some of the evidence comes in with the stipulation with the defense attorney because it's science," Harrington said.

Before cell-phone data and electronic data were accepted as science, legal precedent had to be set for how to admit that data into evidence.

‚ÄúThe landmark case that set the legal standard for the high-tech crime unit's cell-phone, electronic data, it was his case," Harrington said. "He made all those evidentiary decisions."

Those decisions were upheld by the Indiana Supreme Court.

Before Williams's retirement celebration in his courtroom on Jan. 16, he was in his office boxing up decades of mementos, including those from his days coaching soccer and keepsakes from his lifelong passion for baseball and the New York Yankees.

Harry Rocheville, a bailiff at the courthouse, a Boston Red Sox fan and a retired police officer from Salem, Massachusetts, walked into the office that afternoon with a box labeled "Yankees Junk!"

Red Sox fans generally are not fond of the Yankees or their fans.

‚ÄúThe only bad thing about Judge Williams is he‚Äôs a Yankees‚Äô fan,‚Äù Rocheville jokingly said weeks earlier.

Ironically, Williams's son, Sam, turned out to be a Red Sox fan.

'It wouldn't be a father-son relationship if we didn't have something like that," Williams joked.

As a kid, Williams watched his idol, famed New York Yankee Mickey Mantle, play in the 1960s, but he never was able to meet him. He has a baseball card collection that includes most, if not all, of Mantle's cards.

Williams admitted he's fortunate to have seen the Yankees play in every stadium they've had, and he has some treasured signed baseballs and a Yankees' ticket stub from the last season they used paper tickets.

Williams' love of baseball is well known by those who know him or visited his office.

He played shortstop during his four years at Hamilton College, and played summer ball when school wasn't in session.

Even though he's lived in Lafayette for nearly 40 years, he still makes it back to watch the Yankees.

When the Journal & Courier interviewed Williams in December, he pointed to a corner of his office, where he had a 5-foot wooden sculpture representing Babe Ruth.

"Shay got me that one year for Christmas," Williams said of the Babe Ruth sculpture. "She said, 'It can't stay home.' So I had that over in my office over at Ball Eggleston."

He had no idea where he's going to put it now that he's retired.

A bookcase on a wall in his office had a Yankees' cap hanging on one end and a pitted and scuffed batting helmet on the other end.

Williams' keepsake helmet is from his college days, and he was wearing it in practice when a loose pitch came his way.

‚ÄúI got beaned,‚Äù Williams said of the pitch that hit him in the side of the head. ‚ÄúWe then changed to flaps.‚Äù

Officially, Williams is retired now, but he's still frequently in the office.

Unofficially, he'll continue to be on the judicial benches in Indiana serving as a senior judge where needed. He also has a few Superior 1 cases he needs to tidy up.

He also plans to continue to teach at Purdue University. His wife, Shay, is not retiring, Williams said.

The voters will choose Williams's replacement in the November elections. Until then, Indiana Gov. Mike Braun appointed Kevin McDaniel to fill out his term. Before he was appointed, McDaniel filed to run for Tippecanoe Superior 1 judge.

Reach Ron Wilkins at rwilkins@jconline.com. Follow on Twitter: @RonWilkins2.

This article originally appeared on Lafayette Journal & Courier: Judge retires after 17 years on the bench and nearly 38 in Lafayette

title: NASA is about to send people to the moon ‚Äî in a spacecraft not everyone thinks is safe to fly
description: As the four-person crew of Artemis II prepares to launch on a historic mission around the moon as soon as February, some experts are worried about the Orion spacecraft‚Äôs heat shield.
fullText:
When four astronauts begin a historic trip around the moon as soon as February 6, they‚Äôll climb aboard NASA‚Äôs 16.5-foot-wide Orion spacecraft with the understanding that it has a known flaw ‚Äî one that has some experts urging the space agency not to fly the mission with humans on board. But NASA remains confident it has a handle on the problem and the vehicle can bring the crew home safely.

The issue relates to a special coating applied to the bottom part of the spacecraft, called the heat shield. It‚Äôs a crucial piece of hardware designed to protect the astronauts from extreme temperatures as they‚Äôre descending back to Earth during the final stretch of their moon-bound mission called Artemis II.

This vital part of the Orion spacecraft is nearly identical to the heat shield flown on Artemis I, an uncrewed 2022 test flight. That prior mission‚Äôs Orion vehicle returned from space with a heat shield pockmarked by unexpected damage ‚Äî prompting NASA to investigate the issue.

And while NASA is poised to clear the heat shield for flight, even those who believe the mission is safe acknowledge there is unknown risk involved.

‚ÄúThis is a deviant heat shield,‚Äù said Dr. Danny Olivas, a former NASA astronaut who served on a space agency-appointed independent review team that investigated the incident. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no doubt about it: This is not the heat shield that NASA would want to give its astronauts.‚Äù

Still, Olivas said he believes after spending years analyzing what went wrong with the heat shield, NASA ‚Äúhas its arms around the problem.‚Äù

Upon completing the investigation about a year ago, NASA determined it would fly the Artemis II Orion capsule as is, believing it could ensure the crew‚Äôs safety by slightly altering the mission‚Äôs flight path.

In a statement to CNN on Friday, NASA said the agency ‚Äúconsidered all aspects‚Äù when making that decision, noting there is also ‚Äúuncertainty that comes with the development and qualification of the processes of changing the manufacturing process of the Avcoat ablator blocks.‚Äù

Basically, NASA said, there‚Äôs uncertainty involved no matter which course of action it takes.

‚ÄúI think in my mind, there‚Äôs no flight that ever takes off where you don‚Äôt have a lingering doubt,‚Äù Olivas said. ‚ÄúBut NASA really does understand what they have. They know the importance of the heat shield to crew safety, and I do believe that they‚Äôve done the job.‚Äù

Lakiesha Hawkins, the acting deputy associate administrator for NASA‚Äôs Exploration Systems Development Mission Directorate, echoed that sentiment in September, saying, ‚Äúfrom a risk perspective, we feel very confident.‚Äù

And Reid Wiseman, the astronaut set to command the Artemis II mission, has expressed his confidence.

‚ÄúThe investigators discovered the root cause, which was the key‚Äù to understanding and solving the heat shield issue, Wiseman told reporters last July. ‚ÄúIf we stick to the new reentry path that NASA has planned, then this heat shield will be safe to fly.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat they‚Äôre talking about doing is crazy,‚Äù said Dr. Charlie Camarda, a heat shield expert, research scientist and former NASA astronaut.

Camarda ‚Äî who was also a member of the first space shuttle crew to launch after the 2003 Columbia disaster ‚Äî is among a group of former NASA employees who do not believe that the space agency should put astronauts on board the upcoming lunar excursion. He said he has spent months trying to get agency leadership to heed his warnings to no avail.

‚ÄúWe could have solved this problem way back when,‚Äù Camarda, who worked as a NASA research scientist for two decades before becoming an astronaut, said of the heat shield issue. ‚ÄúInstead, they keep kicking the can down the road.‚Äù

Now, the agency appears on track to green-light Artemis II for takeoff, as its leaders have sought to assure the public ‚Äî and the crew ‚Äî the mission will be safe.

The Orion spacecraft was rolled to its launchpad atop the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket on January 17. And a crucial milestone could be days away as Artemis program leaders gather for final risk assessments and the flight readiness review, a meeting in which top brass will determine whether the Artemis II rocket and spacecraft are ready to take off with NASA‚Äôs Wiseman, Victor Glover and Christina Koch, and the Canadian Space Agency‚Äôs Jeremy Hansen, on board.

Even before Artemis, the Orion capsule ‚Äî a $20.4 billion spacecraft that NASA spent 20 years developing ‚Äî was not exactly a darling of the aerospace community. Resentment for the vehicle has been brewing in various pockets of the industry for some time.

One engineer and physicist who previously worked on advanced technology development but did not work directly on the Artemis program derided Orion as ‚Äúflaming garbage.‚Äù A former employee at NASA‚Äôs Jet Propulsion Laboratory, he decried the capsule‚Äôs exceptionally long development timeline and cost overruns that have ballooned into the billions of dollars.

Lori Garver, a former deputy administrator for NASA under the Obama administration, has publicly lamented the politicking that colored the vehicle‚Äôs path to completion.

But Orion‚Äôs issues can‚Äôt be fully pinned on politics, said Dr. Ed Pope, a heat shield and material science expert who founded Matech, a California-based missile defense technology company. Pope did not participate in NASA‚Äôs heat shield investigation.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a Republican thing or a Democrat thing at all,‚Äù Pope told CNN. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a bureaucrat thing.‚Äù

The decisions that led up to the heat shield issues NASA is grappling with today began early in the spacecraft‚Äôs development process, according to Pope.

Orion program managers chose to make the spacecraft‚Äôs heat shield out of Avcoat material in 2009. The heat shields manufactured for NASA‚Äôs Apollo capsules all had a protective Avcoat layer, so leaders viewed it as a well-understood material with decades of data to back up its effectiveness.

For an uncrewed test flight in 2014, called EFT-1, the mission team outfitted an Orion capsule with a heat shield applied in the same manner as in the Apollo era ‚Äî in an intricate honeycomb-like structure.

But that approach required a tedious manufacturing process that NASA hoped to avoid.

‚ÄúIt was very finicky, and it was going to be really, really hard to reproduce that quickly,‚Äù said Pam Melroy, a longtime NASA employee, former astronaut and Air Force officer who once served as deputy administrator of the space agency. ‚ÄúThat was part of the reason why we said, ‚ÄòLet‚Äôs just make this a simpler design.‚Äô It was really all about producibility.‚Äù

Even before the EFT-1 test flight launched, NASA program managers wanted to alter the design, according to Melroy. Though NASA said in a statement the final decision was made in 2015.

NASA also said the honeycomb-structured Avcoat experienced issues during manufacturing for EFT-1, noting ‚Äúcracks in seams appeared between the different honeycomb sections‚Äù and the material did not cure evenly and was weaker than expected. That made it ‚Äúmarginally acceptable‚Äù for the 2014 test flight and likely unusable for a lunar mission that requires far faster speeds and a more violent reentry process.

Textron Systems, the Texas-based company that produces Avcoat, told CNN in a statement that in 2015 it ‚Äúlicensed the Avcoat material to Lockheed Martin, who is contracted by NASA to manufacture the heat shields for the Artemis program‚Äù and deferred further comment to the aerospace giant.

Blaine Brown, director of Orion Spacecraft Mechanical Systems at Lockheed Martin Space, confirmed in a statement to CNN that the Avcoat structure was altered ‚Äúto increase manufacturing and installation efficiency.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe support NASA‚Äôs decision to fly the Artemis II mission with its current heat shield and are committed to seeing Orion safely launch and return on its historic mission to the Moon with crew onboard,‚Äù Brown said.

The Orion capsules built for the Artemis missions abandoned the Avcoat honeycomb structure in favor of a heat shield constructed using large blocks of the material.

‚ÄúOur experience with a block design on Mars heat shields showed us that blocks were easier to produce, test and install,‚Äù Brown said.

The first real-world test of the new Orion heat shield design, however, came with the Artemis I test flight in 2022. After that mission, NASA found chunks of the heat shield had broken off, leaving divots in the charred Avcoat material.

That is not how the heat shield is supposed to behave. The Avcoat layer is meant to erode in a controlled manner as it heats.

NASA disclosed the problem months after Orion returned from space in 2022. The agency‚Äôs office of the inspector general then released images of the ravaged Artemis I heat shield in a 2024 report.

Further complicating the situation was the fact that by that point it was already too late to fix the heat shield for Artemis II.

NASA did not ‚Äî and could not ‚Äî replace the Artemis II heat shield with a new one. The Orion capsule slated for the mission already had its heat shield installed even before Artemis I flew, and ‚Äúyou couldn‚Äôt just go to Billy Bob‚Äôs heat shield removal shop‚Äù to replace it, Olivas noted.

The investigation into the Artemis I heat shield issue also concluded that even though there were no astronauts on board the test flight, ‚Äúflight data showed that had crew been aboard, they would have been safe.‚Äù

When asked about NASA‚Äôs decision to move forward with the Artemis II mission without replacing the heat shield, Melroy, who oversaw the heat shield investigation as deputy administrator, said that NASA ‚Äúprogram managers sometimes have to make these trades for cost, schedule and performance, and they certainly didn‚Äôt undertake that decision lightly.‚Äù

Heat shields produced for future Artemis missions will be manufactured with upgraded techniques, NASA leaders revealed in a December 2024 news conference.

Specifically, the agency plans to alter the ‚Äúbillet mold loading‚Äù essentially altering how much Avcoat is loaded into a mold to ultimately produce a more permeable shield, NASA said in its Friday statement to CNN.

In the meantime, analysis of what went wrong during the 2022 test flight is informing a new approach for this year‚Äôs upcoming mission.

Avcoat is ablative, meaning the material is designed to char and erode in a controlled manner as the spacecraft comes roaring back from the moon and dips back into the thick inner band of Earth‚Äôs atmosphere while still traveling more than 30 times the speed of sound.

This phase of flight, called ‚Äúreentry,‚Äù causes a violent compression of air molecules that can heat the spacecraft‚Äôs exterior to more than 5,000 degrees Fahrenheit (2,760 degrees Celsius).

NASA engineers designed the Orion spacecraft for a ‚Äúskip reentry‚Äù ‚Äî the capsule acts like a flat stone skipping atop the surface of a still lake as it dips briefly into the atmosphere and briefly raises its altitude once more before final descent. The special trajectory allows Orion to target a precise splashdown location.

In 2024, NASA twice opted to delay the timeline for the Artemis II launch in part to allow more time to collect data.

The problem, NASA concluded after months of research, was that the Avcoat material used in the Artemis I heat shield was not permeable enough. That meant that when the Orion capsule dipped into the atmosphere, gases built up in the heat shield‚Äôs interior, causing chunks of the material to break off and cracks to form.

None of the experts interviewed by CNN dispute this characterization of why the Artemis I heat shield did not perform as expected.

Up for debate is how well NASA‚Äôs Artemis mission managers understand the problem and exactly how much risk the suboptimal heat shield poses to the four astronauts slated to launch in a few weeks.

In September, some of the space agency‚Äôs Artemis program leaders said they believed Orion‚Äôs heat shield would perform well on Artemis II, despite there being no substantial changes to its design.

In fact, while NASA now plans to manufacture future heat shields to be permeable, Artemis II‚Äôs heat shield is actually less permeable than the one built for Artemis I.

About 6% of the Artemis I heat shield‚Äôs surface area was permeable, Olivas noted, and that permeable area did not suffer any cracking. But the Artemis II heat shield, he added, does not have any permeable areas, noting that change was made prior to the Artemis I test flight and before NASA realized the heat shield needed to be permeable to perform well.

Rick Henfling, the Artemis flight director leading reentry, said during a September news conference that the Artemis II reentry trajectory has been modified with the goal of avoiding the conditions that caused the Artemis I heat shield to crack.

‚ÄúWe won‚Äôt go as high on that skip, it‚Äôll just be a loft,‚Äù Henfling said.

This new reentry path, Henfling said, should allow the Avcoat material to erode normally.

‚ÄúWe want to emphasize that safety is our top priority,‚Äù Hawkins added, repeating a long-held NASA mantra.

The decision to use an altered trajectory was made after extensive testing, NASA said in its Friday statement. And the adjusted return path is designed to create ‚Äúa steeper descent angle to reduce exposure time at peak heating, thus minimizing further char loss.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis thorough testing, analysis, simulation, and expert validation collectively formed NASA‚Äôs official flight rationale providing sufficient justification to proceed without redesigning the heat shield,‚Äù the statement reads.

Other experts, however, disagree that changing Orion‚Äôs flight path is enough to guarantee that the crew will make it home safely.

‚ÄúThe reason this is such a big deal is that when the heat shield is spalling ‚Äî or you have big chunks coming off ‚Äî even if the vehicle isn‚Äôt destroyed, you‚Äôre right at the point of incipient failure now,‚Äù said Dr. Dan Rasky, an expert on advanced entry systems and thermal protection materials who worked at NASA for more than 30 years.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like you‚Äôre at the edge of the cliff on a foggy day,‚Äù Rasky said.

Rasky, like Camarda, does not believe that NASA should allow astronauts to fly on board the Artemis II Orion capsule.

Even some experts who believe Artemis II is safe to fly acknowledge that the Orion heat shield will likely crack and display signs of damage upon its return from Earth, even with the modified trajectory.

‚ÄúWill the heat shield crack? Yes, it‚Äôs going to crack,‚Äù Olivas, the astronaut who aided NASA‚Äôs heat shield investigation, said.

But Orion has some built-in ‚Äúrobustness,‚Äù said Dr. Steve Scotti, a distinguished research associate at NASA‚Äôs Langley Research Center in Hampton, Virginia, who served as a volunteer on an advisory team that was involved in the Artemis I heat shield investigation.

Underneath the Avcoat layer, Scotti said, lies a composite structure that during testing has been able to briefly survive the extreme temperatures of reentry. And that structure could serve as a last line of defense in the unlikely case that the Avcoat material becomes so deformed it begins to expose the underside of the spacecraft, Scotti said.

The composite structure wasn‚Äôt put there as a fail-safe or backup for the heat shield ‚Äî but it‚Äôs lucky it is there, Scotti said.

Olivas emphasized that NASA isn‚Äôt expecting to rely on the composite structure to keep the astronauts safe. The Avcoat material should still do that, he said. But the structure does provide an extra layer of safety, Olivas noted.

And even if the Artemis II heat shield performs worse than it did during Artemis I, Olivas and Scotti are confident the astronauts will remain safe.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have any strong fears that the crew is in danger,‚Äù Scotti told CNN, echoing Olivas‚Äô sentiments.

But neither Scotti‚Äôs nor Olivas‚Äô expressions of optimism come without an asterisk. Both experts acknowledge, as Camarda argues, that engineers cannot possibly predict exactly how the heat shield will behave.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs very little data to be able to put into an analysis‚Äù of the heat shield, Scotti told CNN. ‚ÄúThe material itself changes every 20 seconds or so during reentry,‚Äù he said, referring to the Avcoat layer.

‚ÄúWe still have things we don‚Äôt know,‚Äù Scotti added. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not low risk, it‚Äôs a moderate risk.‚Äù

Scotti‚Äôs and Olivas‚Äô votes of confidence in the Artemis II mission were hard won.

Olivas, in fact, held serious doubts about NASA‚Äôs intention to fly the Artemis II mission with crew until he sat through a three-hour meeting at the space agency‚Äôs headquarters in Washington, DC, on January 8.

CNN requested and was denied access to the meeting. Only two journalists were invited to attend, and the meeting was expected to be largely off the record because confidential information was being discussed.

NASA‚Äôs newly installed administrator, Jared Isaacman, convened the meeting to gauge dissenting opinions, he told CNN affiliate station WESH in Orlando.

The meeting, Isaacman said, ‚Äúonly reaffirmed my confidence in the decisions of the bright engineers at NASA.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe have modified our reentry profile. We have regained margin to safety, and I feel very good about that with Artemis II,‚Äù he added.

But Olivas said his hesitations were absolved by a presentation from a ‚ÄúTiger Team‚Äù ‚Äî a NASA term for a specialized team brought together to solve a complex problem ‚Äî at Johnson Space Center in Houston.

‚ÄúThe key parameter here is: When is the heat shield going to crack? And how deep into the atmosphere are you going to be if it does crack?‚Äù Olivas said.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs things that we can never know until it actually happens,‚Äù he added, referring to the heat shield. But the Tiger Team‚Äôs analysis gave him confidence that NASA understood the Avcoat material well enough to be certain the crew would not be in danger.

‚ÄúThe Tiger Team did a phenomenal job,‚Äù Olivas said. ‚ÄúI trust those engineers emphatically, and the program managers who are driving them.‚Äù

That, however, is where Camarda ‚Äî who also attended the January 8 meeting at NASA headquarters ‚Äî disagrees.

Camarda takes issue, for example, with a computer program that the Tiger Team used in its heat shield analysis.

Called the Crack Indication Tool, or CIT, it was meant to model how and when the Avcoat material might begin fragmenting in various conditions.

What if Orion were to take a smaller ‚Äúskip‚Äù before making its final plunge?

The CIT is meant to churn out data about how such changes might impact the heat shield ‚Äî and whether those scenarios would trigger cracking.

But the data is imperfect, Camarda argues, and the tool relies on ‚Äúsimplifying assumptions.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe analysis is a simplistic model to predict gas generation, material charring and qualitatively when cracks happen,‚Äù Camarda said. ‚ÄúBut the failure mechanism is how the cracks grow, and it definitely can‚Äôt predict that. It cannot predict the stresses and strains that cause the cracks or how they can grow.‚Äù

When asked about Camarda‚Äôs criticisms of the CIT, Olivas acknowledged that no computer modeling program is completely accurate. And the CIT cannot predict crack growth.

But among the data points that assuaged Olivas‚Äô concerns, he said, was the fact that the Tiger Team lined up the computer program‚Äôs predictions with real-world lab tests involving Avcoat material. The CIT was also able to correctly predict and re-create the conditions that led to the cracking on Artemis I.

‚ÄúThat gave me a confidence that the tool itself was indeed a good predictor,‚Äù Olivas said.

But, Camarda counters, it is possible to create modeling tools that take a more interdisciplinary approach.

‚ÄúA multi-physics analysis can do everything in one computer code,‚Äù Camarda said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs predicting the aero thermodynamic heating on the outside of the vehicle, and studying how the material changes phases and starts to burn and produces gases.‚Äù

That, he said, is the type of analysis that could give program managers a more holistic understanding of the risks this heat shield poses.

To Camarda, the heat shield problem is one symptom of a widespread ailment plaguing NASA that took root in the shuttle era. His view of the agency is informed by his experience as a young astronaut preparing to fly when the Space Shuttle Columbia broke apart during reentry in 2003, killing all seven passengers.

It marked the second tragedy for the program after the Space Shuttle Challenger was destroyed during ascent in 1986.

In a phone interview with CNN, Camarda highlighted that in the early 1980s, NASA had estimated that the space shuttle would have a roughly 1 in 100,000 chance of experiencing a deadly malfunction.

Ultimately, however, the shuttle flew a total of 135 missions with two explosions, resulting in 14 total casualties. That put the vehicle‚Äôs actual odds of experiencing a catastrophic failure at 1 in 67.5.

At one point during his NASA career, Camarda was appointed head of engineering at Johnson Space Center only, he said, to be pushed out from that role after vocally expressing concerns about mission safety in the aftermath of the Columbia disaster, he wrote in ‚ÄúMission Out of Control,‚Äù a memoir and technical deep dive about his years at the agency.

Camarda‚Äôs former boss did not respond to an email request for comment.

Camarda ultimately left NASA in 2019 after 45 years of service.

In his view, the space agency has shifted away from a research and discovery mindset that it embodied during the Apollo era ‚Äî when engineers were encouraged to identify and express concerns about potential safety issues as they picked apart engineering challenges on a fundamental level.

In today‚Äôs climate, Camarda said, he worries NASA employees are encouraged to fall in line with the assessments and goals of the agency‚Äôs management and leadership.

Edgar Zapata, a retired Kennedy Space Center engineer who still serves on the NASA Innovative Advanced Concepts (NIAC) External Council, a program that aims to fund bleeding-edge technology development, said he shares Camarda‚Äôs concerns.

‚ÄúI think our experiences are shaded by having seen that once this body politic decides, almost by mysterious forces, that it‚Äôs going to do something ‚Äî it tends to figure out a way to move forward,‚Äù Zapata said of NASA‚Äôs decision-making process and risk assessments.

NASA spokespeople did not respond to a request for comment about criticisms from Camarda regarding the agency‚Äôs culture. NASA has long maintained and emphasized that it considers safety to be its top priority.

Camarda also emphasized that his opposition to Artemis II isn‚Äôt driven by a belief it will end with a catastrophic failure. He thinks it‚Äôs likely the mission will return home safely.

More than anything, Camarda told CNN, he fears that a safe flight for Artemis II will serve as validation for NASA leadership that its decision-making processes are sound. And that‚Äôs bound to lull the agency into a false sense of security, Camarda warned.

The two former astronauts and heat shield experts ‚Äî Olivas and Camarda ‚Äî do not share the same opinion about whether NASA should launch the Artemis II mission with crew on board. But on this point, they agree: ‚ÄúSometimes we get lucky. And when we get lucky, sometimes we trade that for being good ‚Äî and then we convince ourselves we‚Äôre better than we really are,‚Äù Olivas told CNN.

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs valid to question what‚Äôs happening at NASA,‚Äù Olivas added, ‚Äúbecause our history is not perfect.‚Äù

NASA‚Äôs Artemis program is sending humans into deep space for the first time in five decades. 

Editor‚Äôs note: This story has been updated with additional information.

title: A Kremlin official confirms that U.S.-brokered Russia-Ukraine talks are resuming this week
description: A new round of U.S.-brokered talks on ending Russia‚Äôs war on Ukraine is set to go ahead this week after a brief postponement, a senior Kremlin official said Monday, with negotiations taking place against a backdrop of continued front-line fighting and deadly long-range attacks on rear areas.  The trilateral talks will take place on Wednesday and Thursday in Abu Dhabi, where a previous meeting was held last month, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov confirmed.  Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said on Sunday that he would be sending a delegation to the meeting, which initially was to be held at the weekend but was delayed by what Peskov said were scheduling conflicts.
fullText:
KYIV, Ukraine (AP) ‚Äî A new round of U.S.-brokered talks on ending Russia‚Äôs war on Ukraine is set to go ahead this week after a brief postponement, a senior Kremlin official said Monday, with negotiations taking place against a backdrop of continued front-line fighting and deadly long-range attacks on rear areas.

The trilateral talks will take place on Wednesday and Thursday in Abu Dhabi, where a previous meeting was held last month, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov confirmed.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said on Sunday that he would be sending a delegation to the meeting, which initially was to be held at the weekend but was delayed by what Peskov said were scheduling conflicts.

The Trump administration has over the past year pushed the two sides to find compromises. But breaking the deadlock on key issues appears no closer as the fourth anniversary of Russia‚Äôs all-out invasion of its neighbor approaches later this month.

Peskov described the talks as ‚Äúvery complex.‚Äù

‚ÄúOn some issues, we have certainly come closer because there have been discussions, conversations, and on some issues it is easier to find common ground,‚Äù he told reporters. ‚ÄúThere are issues where it‚Äôs more difficult to find common ground.‚Äù

Russian presidential envoy Kirill Dmitriev was in Miami, Florida, at the weekend for talks with American officials, but Peskov refused to provide any details of the meeting.

A key sticking point is whether Russia gets to keep the Ukrainian territory its army has occupied, especially in Ukraine's eastern industrial heartland. Moscow is also demanding possession of other Ukrainian land there that it hasn‚Äôt been able to capture.

Russian drones and missiles have continued to bombard civilian areas , killing 12 miners in a bus on Sunday in the most recent mass aerial attack. The barrages have also wrecked the Ukrainian power grid, leaving people without heating, light and running water in bitter winter cold.

Defense Minister Mykhailo Fedorov said Monday that authorities are taking steps to prevent Russia using Starlink satellite services to steer its drones toward their targets.

Fedorov asked Elon Musk‚Äôs SpaceX to help deny Russia use of the service in Ukraine. Starlink is a global internet network that relies on around 10,000 satellites orbiting Earth.

Ukraine is requiring civilian and military Starlink users to register their terminals on a database, allowing approved devices to function while unregistered terminals would be disabled inside Ukraine, Fedorov said.

‚ÄúLooks like the steps we took to stop the unauthorized use of Starlink by Russia have worked,‚Äù Musk said Sunday on X. ‚ÄúLet us know if more needs to be done.‚Äù

Litvinova contributed from Tallinn, Estonia.

Follow AP‚Äôs coverage of the war in Ukraine at https://apnews.com/hub/russia-ukraine

title: Trappers scoop up iguanas ‚Äòby the dozens‚Äô amid South Florida cold snap
description: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre probably at like 2,000 iguanas,‚Äù said Redline Iguana Removal owner Blake Wilkins.
fullText:
South Florida iguana removal companies were scooping up hundreds of cold-stunned and dead lizards Sunday in a seemingly record-breaking roundup due to the cold snap, according to local business owners.

‚ÄúWe are scooping them up by the dozens,‚Äù said Blake Wilkins, owner of Redline Iguana Removal in Hollywood.

It was 35.1 degrees with a wind chill of 27 around 7 a.m. Sunday at Miami Internation Airport, beating the previous Feb. 1 record low of 36, set in 1909. With those cold temps, the iguana removal business was booming.

Iguanas and other reptiles can lose muscle control and go into a state of shock, appearing ‚Äúfrozen,‚Äù when temperatures dip near freezing. On Friday, the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission lifted its normal restrictions and said that on Sunday and Monday, people could trap the iguanas, a non-native invasive species, and bring them to five FWC offices so they could be humanely killed or transferred to permitted pet operators.

Wilkins said his trappers started working from about 5 a.m. to 6 a.m. to take advantage of the weather and had already been to at least 100 locations by Sunday afternoon. At one golf course, Redline Iguana Removal picked up about 100 iguanas within an hour.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre probably at like 2,000 iguanas,‚Äù Wilkins said.

The cold temperatures, combined with the wind knocking the iguanas out of trees, created a ‚Äúkind of double factor,‚Äù he said, adding that he had dodged a falling iguana earlier.

Wilkins said he‚Äôs been removing iguanas for a decade, and this is definitely the strongest cold front with the most frozen iguanas he‚Äôs seen. About 50% of the iguanas removed were dead.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd say it happens every year but not to this magnitude,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThis is a strong one, for sure.‚Äù

The company truck was ‚Äúabsolutely stacked‚Äù with cold-stunned and dead iguanas, and the calls for removal will continue Monday, he said.

‚ÄúIt may be kind of gruesome for people, but it‚Äôs a good idea of what we‚Äôve gotten,‚Äù Wilkins said.

Steve Kavashansky, owner of Iguana Busters in West Palm Beach, joked that he was doing much better than the iguanas were on Sunday. His business offers removal from Jupiter to just north of Miami.

The calls for removal across South Florida have been nonstop, and Iguana Busters hasn‚Äôt had time to take on new customers because it‚Äôs so busy, Kavashansky said. By around 2 p.m., his trappers were on their 45th call of the day.

His company had collected close to 150 iguanas, and the majority of them were cold-stunned rather than dead, he said. From his experience, the iguanas have been acclimating to the cooler temperatures over the years.

‚ÄúLast year, we maybe had five, maybe 10 calls, and that was over the whole winter,‚Äù Kavashansky said. ‚ÄúThis year, just today alone, we are up to 45 calls.‚Äù

While the FWC designated locations for members of the public to drop off captured, cold-stunned iguanas on Sunday and Monday, Kavashansky said he would not recommend picking them up.

The FWC did not respond to a request for comment on how many iguanas were turned over Sunday in South Florida.

A couple of years ago, one woman picked up a stunned iguana and put it in her car, Kavashansky said. The iguana woke up as it warmed up, whipped her with its tail, and she crashed.

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre not trained to deal with these animals, I wouldn‚Äôt do it,‚Äù he said.

title: India hands Apple a win by letting foreign firms fund equipment without tax risk
description: India's government on Sunday handed a major win to Apple by allowing foreign companies to provide machines to their contract manufacturers
fullText:
NEW DELHI, Feb 1 (Reuters) - India's government on Sunday handed a major win to Apple by allowing foreign companies to provide machines to their contract manufacturers in certain areas for five years ‚Äãwithout any tax risk.

Apple has been growing in India in recent years as it diversifies beyond China. Counterpoint Research ‚Äåsays iPhone's share of the Indian market has doubled to 8% since 2022. And while China still accounts for 75% of global iPhone shipments, India's share ‚Äåhas quadrupled to 25% since 2022.

What is Apple's current market position in India?

What tax changes did India make for Apple?

Why was Apple concerned about India's tax laws?

How will this benefit Apple's manufacturing strategy?

Apple had been lobbying India's government to modify its income tax laws to ensure the company is not taxed for ownership of the high-end iPhone machinery it provides to its contract manufacturers.

In India, unlike China, Apple was concerned that if it paid for machines for its contract manufacturers, Indian law could consider that a so-called "business connection" and impose taxes on its iPhone sales profits. ‚Å†That had forced its contract manufacturers Foxconn and ‚ÄåTata to themselves spend billions of dollars on machines.

India on Sunday said that "to promote manufacturing of electronic goods for a contract manufacturer", it is making certain law changes to ensure that mere ownership of ‚Äçmachines by a foreign company does not lead to taxes on it.

The decision was made public as part of Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman's 2026-27 annual budget, presented on Sunday.

The move could prompt Apple and other companies to invest rapidly in the electronics manufacturing space by taking over initial ‚Äãexpenses for pricey machines, reducing the initial cost burden on contract manufacturers they partner with.

"We are saying that if you bring ‚Äåyour machine, and that machine is used by a local manufacturer to produce something, we will ... exempt you for 5 years. We are giving them certainty," Revenue Secretary Arvind Shrivastava said at a post-budget press conference.

FASTER SCALE-UP AND GREATER CONFIDENCE

Smartphone manufacturing is a key plank of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's agenda for economic growth.

The rule change will apply until the 2030-31 tax year and only to factories set up in so-called customs-bonded areas - which are technically considered being outside India‚Äôs customs border. If devices are sold within India from ‚Å†such factories, they will attract import taxes, making such facilities attractive only ‚Äãfor exports.

"Any income arising on account of providing capital goods, equipment or tooling ‚Äãto a contract manufacturer, being a company resident in India, is eligible for exemption," the Indian government said in one of its explanatory budget documents.

title: Iran‚Äôs economy falters as internet shutdown hits people, businesses hard
description: The state-imposed blackout has disconnected Iranians from the world and choked off businesses.
fullText:
Tehran, Iran ‚Äì Iran‚Äôs economic outlook appears increasingly grim more than three weeks after the start of what became one of the most comprehensive and prolonged state-imposed internet blackouts in history, impacting a population of more than 90 million people.

Iranian authorities abruptly cut off all communications across the country on the night of January 8, at the height of nationwide protests that the United Nations and international human rights organisations say were suppressed with the use of deadly force.

Most of Iran‚Äôs internet bandwidth, local and international phone calls and SMS text messages have been restored over recent days. But most of the country is still unable to freely connect to the global internet amid heavy filtering by the state.

The increased bandwidth allows more people to circumvent state restrictions using a variety of proxies and virtual private networks (VPNs), but solutions are often costly and temporary.

Last week, Information and Communications Technology Minister Sattar Hashemi told reporters his ministry estimates that the Iranian economy suffered at least 50 trillion rials (about $33m at the current exchange rate) in damages on a daily basis during the blackout.

But the minister admitted that the true toll is likely much higher, and said that other ministers and economic officials have privately offered heftier estimates that he did not expand upon.

The government of President Masoud Pezeshkian has said the decision to fully block connectivity was taken outside of its control by the Supreme National Security Council.

Pezeshkian, who had made scaling back internet filtering a main campaign promise, has refrained from talking about Iran‚Äôs largest internet blackout to date, instead focusing on economic reforms and cash subsidies.

The administration has promised to offer online businesses financial support, but the losses have already been sudden, acute, and too heavy to bear for many.

Simin Siami, a travel agent working in Tehran, told Al Jazeera that her company lost most of its income and had to lay off a number of employees.

‚ÄúMost international flights were cancelled, and there was no way to purchase tickets or compare existing flights,‚Äù she said, adding that her company was also unable to book hotels for customers, who were initially even unable to renew their passports.

‚ÄúUnfortunately, that limited our services to selling tickets for local flights and booking local hotels, and cancelled all our previous international tickets and bookings.‚Äù

title: Epstein Island Joke From Trevor Noah At Grammys Sends Trump Into Lawsuit-Threatening Tizzy: ‚ÄúA Total Loser, Better Get His Facts Straight‚Äù
description: If Trevor Noah really wanted a response from Donald Trump on his mocking question of ‚ÄúWhat are you going to do about it?‚Äù during the Grammys on Sunday night, the former Apprentice host just gave it to him, maybe. As he has with so many critics, those who poke fun at him and almost anything ‚Ä¶
fullText:
If Trevor Noah really wanted a response from Donald Trump on his mocking question of ‚ÄúWhat are you going to do about it?‚Äù during the Grammys on Sunday night, the former Apprentice host just gave it to him, maybe.

As he has with so many critics, those who poke fun at him and almost anything to do with Jeffrey Epstein, Trump is threatening to take Noah to court.

Trevor Noah Takes Shots At Nicki Minaj, Donald Trump‚Äôs Epstein Association & More During Grammys Show

Trump Celebrity Supporters: Famous Folks In Favor Of The 47th President

Alex Warren Shares What He Heard During Grammy Audio Glitch: "This Would Only Happen To Me"

‚ÄúIt looks like I‚Äôll be sending my lawyers to sue this poor, pathetic, talentless, dope of an M.C., and suing him for plenty,‚Äù the notoriously thin-skinned Trump posted online Sunday, not long after the Kendrick Lamar and Bad Bunny dominated the 68th annual Grammy Awards on CBS. ‚ÄúAsk Little George Slopadopolus, and others, how that all worked out. Also ask CBS! Get ready Noah, I‚Äôm going to have some fun with you!‚Äù

Proving that he loves to watch and loves to remind everyone who has already kissed the ring and written the checks, POTUS‚Äô long, enraged and uppercase-strewn post on his Truth Social platform denounced the music industry‚Äôs big night and Noah‚Äôs last turn as Grammy host. No surprise, it was all because of a bipartisan crack by the ex-Daily Show host about that past presidential pal and deceased pedophile Epstein ‚Äî as you can see here:

Trevor Noah takes another jab at Donald Trump #Grammys: ‚ÄúSong of the Year ‚Äî that is a Grammy that every artist wants almost as much as Trump wants Greenland, which makes sense because Epstein‚Äôs island is gone, he needs a new one to hang out with Bill Clinton‚Äù pic.twitter.com/quUWEpX4NL

‚Äî Deadline (@DEADLINE) February 2, 2026

Generating a roar from the music crowd over his swipe at Trump, Noah‚Äôs quip of ‚Äúwhat are you going to do about it?‚Äù was born out of the reality that 2026 is going to be his final time hosting the Grammys after several years fronting the shindig.

Trump didn‚Äôt give a toss about any of that.

‚ÄúNoah said, INCORRECTLY about me, that Donald Trump and Bill Clinton spent time on Epstein Island,‚Äù Trump digitally raged. ‚ÄúWRONG!!! I can‚Äôt speak for Bill, but I have never been to Epstein Island, nor anywhere close, and until tonight‚Äôs false and defamatory statement, have never been accused being there, not even by the Fake News Media.‚Äù

The remarks by Noah and the reaction by Trump comes just a couple of days after the MAGA Overlord‚Äôs Department of Justice dumped millions of redacted pages and hundreds of thousands of black-barred images from the long-delayed and much-anticipated Epstein Files. Still, with speculation that there is much more not out there despite congressional demands, Trump‚Äôs name comes up various times in what was released on January 30, including some pretty horrific allegations and new details. Among those also mentioned are L.A. Olympics boss Casey Wasserman, Elon Musk, ex-POTUS Clinton, Melania docu director Brett Ratner, Bill Gates (and some ‚ÄúRussian girl‚Äù), Jay-Z, the now-former Prince Andrew of Windsor, Harvey Weinstein, and of course Epstein‚Äôs right-hand lady and current federal convict Ghislaine Maxwell.

While admitting he knew Epstein back in the roaring ‚Äô80s and ‚Äô90s, Trump always has denied he got up to anything inappropriate with or via him. As accusations against the one-time openly philandering Trump have been made by alleged Epstein victims and others (as well as cringy video of Trump and Epstein and correspondence between the two), little has made it to the courts connecting him to the horrors of sex trafficking and more.

Suspicion of how deep Trump really went with Epstein, who died in 2019 by what was termed suicide in police custody has become a benchmark for Democrats and others ‚Äì even when the likes of Clinton and former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers have also been caught in the ugly web. The massive files release of January 30 even found Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche¬†having to insist more than once the DOJ wasn‚Äôt and hadn‚Äôt been covering up for POTUS ‚Äî to almost no avail.

Having started on CBS when Trump hero Richard Nixon was in the White House in 1973, tonight was the last time the Grammys will be seen on the now David Ellison-owned network.

Starting in 2027, the ceremony will be broadcast on ABC as part of¬†the Grammys‚Äô 10-year deal with Disney,¬†which was announced last year. As the Oscars leave ABC for YouTube in 2029, the¬†Grammys¬†will air on¬†ABC,¬†Hulu¬†and Disney+ from next year all the way to 2036 ‚Äì when a then 90-year-old Trump will almost certainly not be president, maybe.

title: Spring forecast could have some surprises for Michigan
description: Here are the AccuWeather highlights of the spring forecast for Michigan and the Great Lakes region.
fullText:
While we‚Äôre still deep into the thick of winter, stretches of sunshine already have us snow-bound Michiganders dreaming about spring.

AccuWeather has released an early peek at the spring forecast, looking at what‚Äôs ahead for each region in the country. For us in the Great Lakes, we might want to temper our excitement. Spring looks like it could be colder than normal once the calendar flips to March.

Michigan is part of a group of 16 states that are expected to see a slower transition to springlike weather this year. All these states are in the Great Lakes area, Upper Midwest, Northeast and Northwest parts of the U.S.

‚ÄúThe transition to warmer spring weather will be slower across the Northeast, Great Lakes and the Pacific Northwest this year, compared to historical averages,‚Äù AccuWeather Lead Long-Range Expert Paul Pastelok said. ‚ÄúWarmer springlike weather is expected to arrive early this year across much of the Southwest, from Southern California to Texas.‚Äù

This slower transition to spring is being shaped by a slower jet stream, a strong storm track expected in the South, and the fading of the La Ni√±a weather pattern.

Here are the AccuWeather highlights of the spring forecast for Michigan and the Great Lakes region:

Cooler start to spring with late-season snow and frost potential.

Some flooding likely later from snowmelt and rain.

Fewer tornadoes than 2025, but frequent damaging wind events and flooding downpours.

Michigan Forecast: 2 small snows and 1 big weather milestone. Watch Torregrossa‚Äôs live forecast

Michigan‚Äôs weather highlight this week: A possible day above freezing!

Snow to impact commute in parts of Michigan on Monday

title: Classic Cars That Should Be Worth a Lot More Today
description: From the Datsun 240Z and BMW 2002 to the Porsche 914 and Alfa Romeo GTV, these classics offer real style, character, and driving fun without the sky-high price tags. They‚Äôre smart picks for enthusiasts who want collectibility on a budget.
fullText:
The classic car market can be a puzzling place. While some vehicles command astronomical prices that seem disconnected from reality, others remain surprisingly affordable despite having all the right ingredients for collectibility.

These special gems offer genuine performance, striking looks, or fascinating backstories that should make them far more valuable than their current market prices suggest. But hey, we're not complaining!

The 240Z helped redefine the affordable sports car formula that many manufacturers still chase today. With its long hood, short deck proportions, and genuinely capable inline six engine, period road tests showed performance quick enough to worry entry-level European sports cars, at a fraction of the price.

Clean examples still trade for reasonable money compared to their European contemporaries, despite the Z-car's massive influence on automotive design and its role in establishing Japan as a serious player in the sports car world.

American Motors' answer to the Camaro and Mustang had arguably the cleanest design of any pony car from the era. The Javelin's distinctive fastback profile and well-balanced proportions put it ahead of its more popular rivals in the styling department.

Yet these cars remain overlooked by collectors who gravitate toward the Big Three offerings, making the Javelin one of the best bargains in the muscle car space.

Few cars blend Italian passion with practical usability quite like the GTV. Its Bertone-designed coupe body wrapped around Alfa's sweet-revving twin-cam four-cylinder engine, creating a driving experience that was both spirited and refined.

While other Italian exotics from the period command serious money, the GTV continues to fly under the radar despite offering genuine Alfa character at accessible prices.

The mid-engine 914 was ahead of its time, offering balanced handling and Porsche engineering in a package that purists initially rejected for not being a "real" Porsche. Decades later, the automotive world has embraced mid-engine sports cars, yet the 914 remains the affordable entry point into vintage Porsche ownership.

Its unique targa top design and nimble chassis make it a joy to drive, especially the later 2.0-liter models.

Before the 3 Series became the benchmark for compact sport sedans, there was the 2002. This boxy little BMW practically created the template for European sport sedans with its rear-wheel drive layout, responsive handling, and just enough power to be entertaining.

Despite its historical significance and the rabid following that modern BMW enthusiasts have developed, clean 2002s remain surprisingly attainable compared to other foundational sports cars.

Rally fans know the Fulvia HF for its works competition history, including helping Lancia win the 1972 International Championship for Manufacturers, but the road-going versions remain undervalued. The narrow-angle V4 engine and front-wheel drive layout created a unique character that was both sophisticated and engaging to drive.

These cars combined Italian craftsmanship with genuine performance credentials, yet they trade for a fraction of what other European sports cars from the period command.

The Europa's wedge-shaped fiberglass body wrapped around Lotus's trademark lightweight philosophy, creating one of the purest driving experiences of the era. While it required some mechanical sympathy and wasn't the most practical choice, the Europa offered a lightweight mid-engine driving experience with sharp handling, but not supercar straight-line performance.

Today's values still reflect that accessibility, even though the car's innovative mid-engine design and lightweight philosophy have made it far more influential than its prices suggest.

Saab's quirky sports car combined Scandinavian design sensibilities with a surprisingly capable chassis and a Ford Taunus-sourced V4 engine that Saab used widely in that era. The Sonett's distinctive styling and unconventional engineering approach made it unlike anything else on American roads during its brief production run.

Its rarity and unique character should make it a collector favorite, yet these distinctive coupes remain one of the most affordable ways to own a piece of Swedish automotive history.

General Motors' European division created what many consider a baby Corvette with the GT's dramatic styling and pop-up headlights. The car's Coke-bottle proportions and distinctive profile turned heads everywhere, while the available 1.9-liter engine provided adequate performance for the era.

Despite its connection to GM design trends of the era and a Coke bottle shape that also showed up on contemporary Corvettes, the Opel GT remains surprisingly affordable for such a visually striking car.

These nine cars represent excellent opportunities for enthusiasts who want to own a piece of automotive history without paying premium prices. Each offers something special, whether it's innovative engineering, timeless design, or cultural significance that shaped the industry. The classic car market has a way of eventually recognizing quality, so these undervalued gems might not stay affordable forever.

For now, they represent some of the best values in the collector car world for those willing to look beyond the obvious choices.

title: ‚ÄúI Had No Idea‚Äù: Russell Wilson Denies Jeffrey Epstein Files Claims Tying Him to Private Jet, $140M Deal
description: A newly released batch of Jeffrey Epstein-related documents, released Friday night by the U. S.
fullText:
A newly released batch of Jeffrey Epstein-related documents, released Friday night by the U.S. Justice Department, quickly gained attention after social media claims suggested Russell Wilson was mentioned in connection with a potential private jet purchase. Those claims stemmed from email exchanges included in the release that referenced Wilson while discussing the possible sale of a Gulfstream G-IV aircraft owned by Epstein.

However, Wilson forcefully rejected speculation after his name surfaced in the documents. He made it clear he had no knowledge of, or connection to, the disgraced financier. He addressed the situation directly on X as the documents began circulating.

‚ÄúNOPE!!! ABSOLUTELY NOT! Not TODAY satan!‚Äù Wilson wrote. ‚ÄúSome Random plane broker tried to sell me a plane. I had no idea whose plane and never bought the plane. Never talked nor Never met the man. Thank God!!!‚Äù

The email chain dates back to January 27, 2019, when Wilson was still the Seattle Seahawks‚Äô quarterback and in the midst of negotiating what would later become a $140 million contract extension. The messages were exchanged between Epstein and his longtime pilot, Larry Visoski, and referenced Wilson as a potential buyer through a broker.

One message claimed Wilson had been persistently calling after seeing the aircraft and was interested in securing the jet during his contract negotiations.

The emails also outlined potential deal structures, including an option period that would have required a substantial upfront payment and varying purchase prices depending on upgrades and engine work. However, Wilson was not included in the email chains, and there is no indication that he participated directly in those conversations.

As the documents circulated, Wilson emphasized that he was never informed that the aircraft belonged to Epstein and maintained that no transaction ever took place. He stated that he never purchased the plane and never had any communication with Epstein at any point.

The release of the Epstein-related records has drawn scrutiny across multiple industries, with thousands of pages being examined for notable names and connections.

In Wilson‚Äôs case, he moved quickly to distance himself from any implication, publicly denying any association and underscoring that his only interaction involved a broker with no disclosed link to Epstein.

The post ‚ÄúI Had No Idea‚Äù: Russell Wilson Denies Jeffrey Epstein Files Claims Tying Him to Private Jet, $140M Deal appeared first on The SportsRush.

title: University of Central Florida residents displaced after freezing temperatures impact housing: What we know
description: Crews are actively addressing a situation in which residents living on the University of Central Florida's campus were displaced after severe cold weather.
fullText:
Residents living at The Towers community at the University of Central Florida were displaced after the severe cold.

The university said the freezing cold impacted the chilled water system at The Towers Community on campus.

Air conditioning units in Towers 1, 3 and 4 were recycling outdoor freezing air, the university said.

ORLANDO, Fla. - Crews are actively addressing a situation in which residents living on the University of Central Florida's campus were displaced after severe cold weather.

The chilled water system at The Towers community on the University of Central Florida's campus was impacted by freezing temperatures, Saturday night, the university said in a released statement.

Temperatures in Orlando dipped to 30 degrees Saturday night with temperatures getting colder ‚Äì to 24 degrees ‚Äì by Sunday morning.

A malfunction occurred in Towers 1, 3 and 4, in which air conditioning units were recycling freezing outdoor air, the university said.

The university announced around 3:15 p.m., Feb. 1, that crews were addressing the situation with the hope of reopening the buildings as soon as possible.

As a result of the cold weather impacts on the chilled water system, residents at the Towers were temporarily displaced, the university said.

"The university‚Äôs priority is the safety and well-being of our students, and we are providing support and ongoing updates during this temporary disruption," UCF said in a released statement.

Information in this story was gathered from a statement by the University of Central Florida.

title: Sheriff Gives New Update on Savannah Guthrie‚Äôs Missing Mother Nancy, Calls Her Home a ‚ÄòCrime Scene‚Äô
description: Pima County Sheriff Chris Nanos gave an update on Nancy Guthrie, the 84-year-old mother of Today host Savannah Guthrie who was reported missing over the weekend. Nanos described Nancy‚Äôs home as a ‚Äúcrime scene‚Äù and officials do not believe she left the home on her own, according to a report from WKYT on Monday, February [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
Pima County Sheriff Chris Nanos gave an update on Nancy Guthrie, the 84-year-old mother of Today host Savannah Guthrie who was reported missing over the weekend.

Nanos described Nancy‚Äôs home as a ‚Äúcrime scene‚Äù and officials do not believe she left the home on her own, according to a report from WKYT on Monday, February 2.

Nancy was reported missing in Arizona on Sunday, February 1, when a family member called 911. She was last seen at home in Catalina Foothills on Saturday, January 31, and Nanos described the scene at Nancy‚Äôs home as ‚Äúvery concerning.‚Äù

While he previously said that Nancy, 84, is ‚Äúvery alert, she‚Äôs of good, sound mind‚Äù and has ‚Äúno cognitive issues,‚Äù she‚Äôs ‚Äúnot in good physical health.‚Äù

Savannah, 54, did not appear on Monday‚Äôs episode of Today, but her cohosts Sheinelle Jones and Craig Melvin covered the situation, including a statement from Savannah and her family.

‚ÄúOn behalf of our family, I want to thank everyone for the thoughts, prayers and messages of support. Right now, our focus remains on the safe return of our dear mom,‚Äù the statement read. ‚ÄúWe thank law enforcement for their hard work on this case and encourage anyone with information to contact the Pima County Sheriff‚Äôs Department at 520-351-4900.‚Äù

title: Body of missing teen Hailey Buzbee found in Ohio, attorney says
description: The body of a missing Indiana teenager is believed to have been found in Ohio, according to the attorney for a person of interest in her death.
fullText:
The body of a missing¬†Indiana teenager is believed to have been found in central Ohio, according to the attorney for a person of interest in her death.

Sam Shamansky, the attorney for 39-year-old Tyler Thomas, said on Feb. 2 that authorities believe they have found the body of 17-year-old Hailey Buzbee in Perry County.

Shamansky said Thomas led the FBI to Buzbee's body on Feb. 1.

Thomas, of Columbus, Ohio, has been charged with pandering sexually oriented material involving a minor and tampering with evidence. According to court records, a search of Thomas's phone included sexually oriented videos and photos of Buzbee,¬†some of which Thomas tried to delete.

Buzbee, who lived in the Indianapolis suburb of Fishers and attended Hamilton Southeastern High School, was last seen by her parents on Jan. 5. She is believed to have met Thomas through an online gaming platform and voluntarily left her home to meet him. Fishers police said a vehicle in the area at the time Buzbee left her home was traced back to Thomas.

Franklin County Municipal Court Judge Jim O'Grady set a $1.5 million bond for Thomas on Jan. 31, before Thomas appeared for any hearing.

Court records say Thomas was furloughed, or released temporarily, to the FBI for investigative purposes on Feb. 1 and was then returned to the Franklin County jail.

Thomas appeared for a bond hearing on Feb. 2 in Municipal Court. Judge Jarrod Skinner kept the $1.5 million bond in place and ordered Thomas to have no internet access or unsupervised visits with minors should he post that and be released, court records say.

Officials¬†spoke with Thomas within a few days of Buzbee's disappearance. Thomas reportedly told detectives he had dropped Buzbee off on the side of the road in western Ohio, but an investigation determined that was not true.

Buzbee was initially classified as a runaway, but her case was upgraded to an "endangered missing juvenile" on Jan. 20.

Police searched Thomas' vehicle and home on Jan. 21 and found evidence Buzbee had been there, as well as at a short-term rental in Hocking County. Thomas has not been charged with murder, according to court records in Franklin and Perry counties.

Reporter Bethany Bruner can be reached at¬†bbruner@dispatch.com.

Contact Jake Allen at jake.allen@indystar.com. Follow him on X, formerly Twitter, @Jake_Allen19.

This article originally appeared on Indianapolis Star: Body of Hailey Buzbee found in Ohio, attorney says
